nodes.title: Steve Wozniak
nodes.short_description: Co-founder whose engineering enabled Apple's birth and early success with Jobs.

nodes.title: John Sculley
nodes.short_description: Apple CEO who removed Jobs in 1985, catalyzing NeXT and Pixar paths.

nodes.title: NeXT
nodes.short_description: Company Jobs founded post-Apple, led to his return via acquisition and underpinned macOS.

nodes.title: Pixar Animation Studios
nodes.short_description: Studio Jobs bought and led, Toy Story success made him billionaire, enabling Disney acquisition.

nodes.title: 2003 cancer diagnosis
nodes.short_description: Pancreatic neuroendocrine tumor diagnosis that reshaped Jobs's priorities and succession planning.

nodes.title: Microsoft
nodes.short_description: Competitor whose 1997 investment and Office commitment stabilized Apple during Jobs's return.

nodes.title: Bill Gates
nodes.short_description: Microsoft co-founder who negotiated 1997 deal, rival and counterpart shaping Jobs's strategy.

nodes.title: The Walt Disney Company
nodes.short_description: Acquired Pixar in 2006, making Jobs its largest individual shareholder and a board member.

nodes.title: Bob Iger
nodes.short_description: Disney CEO who championed the Pixar acquisition and became a key ally to Jobs.

nodes.title: Xerox PARC
nodes.short_description: Research center demonstration of GUI and mouse profoundly influenced Jobs's product vision.

nodes.title: Paul Jobs
nodes.short_description: Adoptive father who instilled craftsmanship and work ethic central to Steve's approach.

nodes.title: Mike Markkula
nodes.short_description: Early investor and mentor, board influence shaped Jobs's role and 1985 departure.

nodes.title: Nolan Bushnell
nodes.short_description: Atari founder who hired Jobs, shaping his early career and entrepreneurial path.

nodes.title: India
nodes.short_description: 1974 spiritual journey there deeply influenced Jobs's philosophy, aesthetics, and leadership.

nodes.title: Toy Story (1995)
nodes.short_description: Pixar's first feature film, breakout success transformed Jobs's wealth and stature.
